poem:
Title: 'The Pedestrian Sage'

Midst roaring thoroughfares, a scribe arose,
Allsop, who studied death yet prized the living.
In helmet's form, his wisdom silently imposed,
A guardian within the chaos, unassuming, giving.

His footprints on West Drayton's pilgrim roads,
Felt by unseen lives he's ceaselessly saving.
Beyond his vanishing point, his legacy unfolds,
In every silent heartbeat his research is engraving.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Richard Allsop obituary Since the 1980s, Britain’s roads have become significantly safer. People are alive today because academics such as my friend and colleague Richard Allsop, who has died aged 84, believed that thorough and rigorous research should support changes in public policy. In his first post, as a scientific officer at the government’s Road Research Laboratory in West Drayton, west London, in 1964, he looked at the effectiveness of motorcycle helmets in casualty reduction". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
